awd_titl_txt: REU Site: The Lamat Summer Research Program on High Performance Computing in Astrophysics
awd_abstract_narration:
This award supports the renewal of an REU Site in computational astrophysics at the University of California-Santa Cruz (UCSC). Students will principally be recruited from regional community colleges, where the main selection criteria will be outstanding academic accomplishments and promise of future achievement. Each year, ten selected interns will work closely with mentors at UCSC and will take part in an intensive eight-week introduction to astrophysical research methods and tools with an emphasis on cosmological simulations. The overall goal of the program is not to solely train astrophysicists but to use astrophysical simulations as an exciting medium for imparting a broad array of scientific skills to the participants. 

The REU Site will increase the retention and graduation rates for students enrolled in two-year colleges through inquiry-based learning of concepts related to astronomy and planetary sciences, using state-of-art astrophysical simulations as a common pillar. Through a comprehensive program of research instruction, mentoring, workshops, and support programs at UCSC, students will develop additional skills to advance their educations and careers. The REU Site has developed a Family Astronomy Night lecture series at the partnering diversity-serving institutions, with the dual aims of communicating astronomy to a wide audience, and ensuring that parents of REU students can support their child's academic success.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Sponsored by the National Science Foundation as an REU site, the Lamat program supports students taking part in an intensive eight-week introduction to astrophysical research methods and tools with an emphasis on computational astrophysics. Students are recruited primarily from community colleges in California, where the principal selection criteria is outstanding academic accomplishments and promise of future achievement. Selected interns worked closely with faculty, postdoctoral associates, and PhD students at UCSC, home to one of the largest groups of computational astrophysicists in the world. Key components of the program include intensive research, a winter computational boot camp, academic counseling and mentoring, science workshops and social justice discussions. A primary goal of Lamat is creating healthy spaces for scientific inquiry for the Lamat Fellows through effective mentoring. Positive mentoring and interpersonal connections can instill a sense of belonging, mitigate the impacts of negative organizational climates, and aid in performance and retention. Lamat provides comprehensive mentoring training that empowers mentors and mentees to co-develop a transformative learning space that prepares and inspires mentees for graduate study.

With support from the NSF over the last three years, 52 undergraduates have participated in the Lamat REU program at UCSC: 35 students were supported by NSF REU Lamat funds and 17 students were supported by other grants. Lamat has had a tremendous impact on these participants:

  • Over the project period, 56% of Lamat participants were first generation college students.
  • During the project period, 100 percent of the students (15) who participated in Lamat during their time at community college have transferred or are in the process of transferring (1) to a four-year college. 
  • 10 of the students who were supported by Lamat over the past three years are currently enrolled in or will join astronomy and astrophysics PhD programs this fall at prestigious universities including Princeton, Stanford, Penn State, University of Waterloo (Computer Science), and UC Santa Cruz.
  • 5 of these students received the highly competitive NSF Graduate Research Fellowships. 
  • Additionally, 2 of the students supported by Lamat over the past three years are now enrolled in fully funded masters programs as a bridge to doctoral studies.
  • 8 Lamat participants were invited to present their research at AAS 241, with one participant winning a prestigious Chambliss award and two others receiving honorable mention.
  • One student was awarded the top undergraduate poster prize at the 20th Divisional meeting of the High Energy Astrophysics Division of the AAS.
  • 10 participants in Lamat during the project period were selected to share their posters at the SACNAS conference.
  • Lamat alumni published 8 articles in refereed science journals over the past 3 years.
